The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Warehouse Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.  



Covered Process 1 (i.e. Railcar Storage ? Anhydrous Ammonia) equipment includes one or more 34,000-gallon railcars.  HCC does not own the railcars and therefore is not responsible for the mechanical integrity of the railcar.  However, trained HCC personnel receive, inspect, and release railcars in accordance with its RMPr Railcar Operating Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in the Railcar Operating Procedures.  Transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the railcars to Covered Process 2 is addressed under that specific covered process.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Warehouse Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 2 (i.e. Fertilizer Blending) equipment includes a 34,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia railcar, a phosphoric acid railcar, water supply, railcar nipple adaptors, transfer hoses, emergency shutoff valves, and a mobile pipe reactor (MPR).  The MPR and ancillary equipment is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).   



The IFRC transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar to its MPR in accordance with its PSM Operating Procedures.  The IFRC is responsible for the transfer of anhydrous ammonia when its equipment is connected to the railcar.  The IFRC is responsible for the training of its operators and maintenance personnel.  The Facility requires that the IFRC have in place and demonstrates compliance with its OSHA PSM for the MPR operations.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of Helena Chemical Company (HCC) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at the Port Lavaca Facility, Port Lavaca, TX.  At this Facility, HCC engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of chemicals (i.e. retail) to customers, most of who use HCC's products to support agricultural operations.



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Port Lavaca Facility located at 111 Pinta Road, Port Lavaca, TX 77979.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Port Lavaca Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Port Lavaca Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



HCC is resubmitting this RMP as a 5-Year update.  All relevant sections for a Program 3 PSM/RMPr Facility have been addressed.



FACILITY



The Operations at the Port Lavaca Facility consists of agricultural chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  As related to the PSM/RMPr, the Port Lavaca Facility stores and handles one covered chemical (i.e. anhydrous ammonia) at quantities that exceed the threshold quantity established by EPA.  Two covered processes are operated at this Facility and they include:



o    Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage (NH3)

o    Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending



At this Facility, anhydrous ammonia is blended with water and phosphoric acid to make ammoni

um polyphosphate.  Ammonium polyphosphate is a liquid fertilizer that is used by farmers on a seasonal basis.  Covered process equipment used in this process includes a railcar for the storage of the anhydrous ammonia and a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR).  The railcar is owned by the chemical manufacturer or railroad, and the MPR is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).



The Port Lavaca Facility orders anhydrous ammonia from a chemical vendor and the chemical vendor ships the anhydrous ammonia to the Facility in railcar(s).  The Facility receives and temporarily stores the railcar(s) on its rail spur in accordance with its railcar operating procedures.  When the IFRC arrives to the Facility, the Facility transfers the responsibility of the anhydrous ammonia railcar(s) to the IFRC.  At this point, the IFRC connects the railcar to the MPR by transfer hoses and prepares to operate the MPR to blend the ammonium polyphosphate.  When the IFRC is complete with its operations, the IFRC transfers the responsibility for the railcar back to the Facility.  The Facility then coordinates with the railroad to transfer the anhydrous ammonia railcar back to the chemical vendor.  The Facility releases the railcar in accordance with its railcar operating procedures.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case offsite consequence analyses were completed for both the ammonia storage process and the blending process.  The worst case release scenario is the same for the both the ammonia storage and the blending process because the largest vessel (i.e. a 34,000-gallon railcar) is common to both of the covered processes when connected.  The worst case scenario release for the Port Lavaca Facility was modeled as if the 34,000-gallon railcar was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenarios are d

ifferent for the two processes.  For the railcar storage covered process, the alternative consequence analysis assumes that an operator fails to fully close the vapor valve on the railcar.  For the fertilizer blending process, the alternative consequence analysis assumes that a 3-inch liquid transfer hose is severed during the blending process.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of these types is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices and emergency shutoff valves) and operating procedures that the Facility and the IFRC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Warehouse Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Warehouse Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Warehouse Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Operators are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.  



The Warehouse Manager is responsible for managing the IFRC in accordance with the Contractor PSM/RMP requirements.  However, the IFRC is responsible for ensuring that its Operators are properly trained in the implementation of its OSHA PSM accident prevention program.







EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



HCC's Port Lavaca Facility is a non-responding facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the

past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Port Lavaca Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Port Lavaca Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Port Lavaca Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Calhoun County LEPC.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Port Lavaca Facility.
